descriptionParts: Defines the rigid connectivity between a primary and set of secondary nodes.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: A unique Name is required for some structural packages to create and identify the object.

properties.name: XtoX
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for translations along the X-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative translation along the X-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: YtoY
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for translations along the Y-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative translation along the Y-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: ZtoZ
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for translations along the Z-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative translation along the Z-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: XtoYY
properties.description: True means that a X-translation imposes a rigid Y-axis rotation.

properties.name: XtoZZ
properties.description: True means that a X-translation imposes a rigid Z-axis rotation.

properties.name: YtoXX
properties.description: True means that a Y-translation imposes a rigid X-axis rotation.

properties.name: YtoZZ
properties.description: True means that a Y-translation imposes a rigid Z-axis rotation.

properties.name: ZtoXX
properties.description: True means that a Z-translation imposes a rigid X-axis rotation.

properties.name: ZtoYY
properties.description: True means that a Z-translation imposes a rigid Y-axis rotation.

properties.name: XXtoXX
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for rotations about the X-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative rotation about the X-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: YYtoYY
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for rotations about the Y-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative rotation about the Y-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: ZZtoZZ
properties.description: True defines a rigid connectivity between primary and secondary nodes for rotations about the Z-axis, i.e. true prohibits relative rotation about the Z-axis between primary and secondary nodes.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Enumerator outlining the fixity of a particular degree of freedom. Controls if the DOF should be free, fixed or stiffness based.
Enum values:
-Free: Free to translate or rotate, depending on the DOF.
-Fixed: Fixed in translation or rotation, depending on the DOF.
-FixedNegative: Zero stiffness in the positive direction.
-FixedPositive: Zero stiffness in the negative direction.
-Spring: Linear spring constant.
-SpringNegative: Nonlinear, zero stiffness in the positive direction.
-SpringPositive: Nonlinear, zero stiffness in the negative direction.
-SpringRelative: Spring stiffness between 0-1 relates to the element to which the DOF applies (e.g. bar end stiffness).
-SpringRelativeNegative: Nonlinear, Spring stiffness between 0-1 relates to the element to which the DOF applies (e.g. bar end stiffness), zero stiffness in the positive direction.
-SpringRelativePositive: Nonlinear, Spring stiffness between 0-1 relates to the element to which the DOF applies (e.g. bar end stiffness), zero stiffness in the negative direction.
-NonLinear: Nonlinear spring model.
-Friction: Friction model (relative to the load applied).
-Damped: Damped velocities/accelerations.
-Gap: Gap model.

properties.name: StartPosition
properties.description: Distance along the bar between the start node and the start of the loaded region. If RelativePositions is true, this value will be a normalised length where 0 means start and 1 means end, which means this value needs to be within this range. If RelativePositions is false, this value will be in absolute distances.

properties.name: EndPosition

If RelativePositions is true, this value will be a normalised length where 0 means start and 1 means end, which means this value needs to be within this range. If RelativePositions is false, this value will be in absolute distances.

descriptionParts: Sets modifiers to a SectionProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

properties.name: Area
properties.description: Modifies the Area of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Iy
properties.description: Modifies the Moment of Inertia about the local y-Axis of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Iz
properties.description: Modifies the Moment of Inertia about the local z-Axis of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: J
properties.description: Modifies the Torsion Constant of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Asy
properties.description: Modifies the Shear Area in the local y direction of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Asz
properties.description: Modifies the Shear Area in the local z direction of the SectionProperty. Value of the SectionProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

descriptionParts: Sets modifiers to a SurfaceProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

properties.name: FXX
properties.description: Modifier of the axial stiffness along the local x-axis. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: FYY
properties.description: Modifier of the axial stiffness along the local y-axis. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: FXY
properties.description: Modifier of the the in-plane shear. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: MXX
properties.description: Modifier of the bending stiffness about the local x-axis. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: MYY
properties.description: Modifier of the bending stiffness about the local y-axis. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: MXY
properties.description: Modifier of the in-plane twist stiffness. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: VXZ
properties.description: Modifier of the xz-out of plane shear stiffness. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: VYZ
properties.description: Modifier of the yz-out of plane shear stiffness. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Mass
properties.description: Modifier of the mass. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

properties.name: Weight
properties.description: Modifier of the weight. Value of the SurfaceProperty is multiplied by this value, hence 1 means no scaling applied.

descriptionParts: 1D finite element for structural analysis. Linear 2-noded element defined by a start and end node.For structural conventions and orientation of the bar please see https://github.com/BHoM/documentation/wiki/BHoM-Structural-Conventions.

properties.name: StartNode
properties.description: Defines the start position of the element. Note that Nodes can contain Supports which should not be confused with Releases.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Elements.Node:  0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.

properties.name: EndNode
properties.description: Defines the end position of the element. Note that Nodes can contain Supports which should not be confused with Releases.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Elements.Node:  0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.

properties.name: SectionProperty
properties.description: Section property of the bar, containing all sectional constants and material as well as profile geometry and dimensions, where applicable.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.SectionProperties.ISectionProperty:  Base interface for all bar section properties. Contains the material and all section constants.  This can be of the following types: AluminiumSection, GenericSection, TimberSection, CableSection, CompositeSection, ConcreteSection, ExplicitSection, SteelSection

properties.name: OrientationAngle
properties.description: Controls the local axis orientation of the bar  For non-vertical members the local z is aligned with the global Z and rotated with the orientation angle about the local x.  For vertical members the local y is aligned with the global Y and rotated with the orientation angle about the local x.  A bar is vertical if its projected length to the horizontal plane is less than 0.0001, i.e. a tolerance of 0.1mm on verticality.  For general structural conventions please see  https://github.com/BHoM/documentation/wiki/BHoM-Structural-Conventions.

properties.name: Release
properties.description: Defines the start and end release of the Bar. The releases defines how the bar is attached to its end nodes. If not set, full fixity will be assumed.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.BarRelease:  Defines the releases at the start and end node of a Bar.

properties.name: Support
properties.description: Linear support for the bar. Three translational degrees of freedom and one rotational. The rotational DOF defines constraint about the axis of the bar.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.Constraint4DOF:  Constraint objects with four degrees of freedom, three translational and one rotational. Used for support or release of 1D analytical elements of 2D analytical objects. The Rotational DOF will correspond to rotation about the axis of the object.

properties.name: Offset
properties.description: Offset of the bar as two vectors, one per end node, in bar local coordinates. Defines offsets from centreline to be applied in analysis packages.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Offsets.Offset:  Class defining offsets for bar objects from its end Nodes to be applied in analysis packages.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Edge class to describe the edges of panels (or other objects) by a curve and properties.

properties.name: Curve
properties.description: Curve of the edge. Should be a planar curve if used on panels.  This is a BH.oM.Geometry.ICurve:  The interface for all one-dimensional geometrical objects.  This can be of the following types: Arc, Circle, Ellipse, Line, NurbsCurve, PolyCurve, Polyline

properties.name: Release
properties.description: Release of the edge, defining the connectivity between the host panel and the edge.   Three translational and one rotational degree of freedom, where the rotational refers to the rotation about the axis of the edge.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.Constraint4DOF:  Constraint objects with four degrees of freedom, three translational and one rotational. Used for support or release of 1D analytical elements of 2D analytical objects. The Rotational DOF will correspond to rotation about the axis of the object.

properties.name: Support
properties.description: Support of the edge, used to constrain the edge in space.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.Constraint6DOF:  Constraint objects with six degrees of freedom, three translational and three rotational, used for supports and bar end releases.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Defines the finite element type of the bar and what forces the bar can accommodate, i.e. if the bar should be treated as a bending element or axial only in analysis packages.
Enum values:
-Flexural: Full axial, flexural and torsional behaviour. 2 x 6 DOFs.
-Axial: Axial only. 2 x 3 DOFs. Can be used to model pin-pin elements.
-CompressionOnly: Axial compression only. No tension stiffness. 2 x 3 DOFs.
-TensionOnly: Axial tension only. No compression stiffness. 2 x 3 DOFs.
Enum values:
-Undefined
-Beam
-Column
-Brace
-Cable
-Pile
Enum values:
-Undefined
-Slab
-Wall
-PileCap
-DropPanel
2D finite element mesh for structural analysis. Defined by a list of nodes and faces.

properties.name: Nodes
properties.description: The nodes of the FEMesh. Mesh faces reference these nodes by their position in this list, so it is important to maintain the order.

properties.name: Faces
properties.description: The faces of the FEMesh. Each face contains a list of indices referring to the nodes in the node list it is connecting.

properties.name: Property
properties.description: Defines the thickness property and material of the FEMesh.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.SurfaceProperties.ISurfaceProperty:  Base interface for properties for 2D finite element structural objects such as Panels and FEMeshes.  This can be of the following types: FabricPanelProperty, Ribbed, Waffle, ConstantThickness, LoadingPanelProperty

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Face of an FEMesh. The face is defined by the indices of its nodes in the node list. Geometrical information about position in space is stored on the host FEMesh.

properties.name: NodeListIndices
properties.description: List of which node indices in the host FEMesh node list that this face is connecting.

properties.name: OrientationAngle
properties.description: Defines the angle that the local x and y axes are rotated around the normal (i.e. local z) of the FEMeshFace. The normal of the FEMeshFace is determined by the curl right hand rule dictated by the order of the node list. Local x is found by projecting the global X to the plane of the FEMeshFace and is then rotated with the OrientationAngle, except for the case when the Normal is parallel with the global X. For this case the local y is instead found by projecting global Y to the plane of the FEMeshFace and is then rotated with the OrientationAngle. The remaining local axis is determined by the right hand rule.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: 0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.

properties.name: Position
properties.description: Position of the node in global Cartesian 3D space.  This is a BH.oM.Geometry.Point:  Defines a dimensionless location in three-dimensional space.

properties.name: Orientation
properties.description: Local x, y, and z axes of the node as a vector Basis. Defaults to world axes.  This is a BH.oM.Geometry.Basis:  An ordered set of mutually orthogonal unit vectors defining three-dimensional orientation in space

properties.name: Support
properties.description: Defines the Support property of the Node. If not set, the Node will be assumed to be free to translate and rotate.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.Constraint6DOF:  Constraint objects with six degrees of freedom, three translational and three rotational, used for supports and bar end releases.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Opening of a structural Panel object. Can be used to represent, for example, shafts, windows, and doors.

properties.name: Edges
properties.description: A list of coplanar Edges defining the contour and potential constraints of the Opening.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: 2D element for structural analysis.
The Surface is a freeform surface object defined by a geometrical surface. For planar elements, the Panel is recommended, as it is generally better supported in analysis packages.

properties.name: Extents
properties.description: A geometrical surface defining the 'centre plane` of the surface.  This is a BH.oM.Geometry.ISurface:  The interface for two-dimensional geometrical objects.  This can be of the following types: Extrusion, Loft, NurbsSurface, Pipe, PlanarSurface, PolySurface

properties.name: Property
properties.description: Defines the thickness property and material of the Element.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.SurfaceProperties.ISurfaceProperty:  Base interface for properties for 2D finite element structural objects such as Panels and FEMeshes.  This can be of the following types: FabricPanelProperty, Ribbed, Waffle, ConstantThickness, LoadingPanelProperty

properties.name: PlanarSpring
properties.description: A planar support for the Surface, constraining the movement in the translational degrees of freedom.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.Constraint3DOF:  Constraint objects with three translational degrees of freedom, used for support of 2D analytical objects.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: 2D element for structural analysis.
The Panel is a planar surface object defined by a list of planar 'Edges' (curves with properties) for both external and internal edges (openings).

properties.name: ExternalEdges
properties.description: A list of coplanar Edges defining the external contour and potential constraints of the Panel.

properties.name: Openings
properties.description: A list of Openings of the panel. The edges that make up the openings must be coplanar with the external edges.

properties.name: Property
properties.description: Defines the thickness property and material of the Panel. Orientation of non-isotropic properties are controlled by the OrientationAngle.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.SurfaceProperties.ISurfaceProperty:  Base interface for properties for 2D finite element structural objects such as Panels and FEMeshes.  This can be of the following types: FabricPanelProperty, Ribbed, Waffle, ConstantThickness, LoadingPanelProperty

properties.name: OrientationAngle
properties.description: Defines the angle that the local x and y axes are rotated around the normal (i.e. local z) of the Panel. The normal of the Panel is determined by the right hand curl rule dictated by the order of the edge list. Local x is found by projecting the global X to the plane of the Panel and is then rotated with the OrientationAngle, except for the case when the Normal is parallel with the global X. For this case the local y is instead found by projecting global Y to the plane of the Panel and is then rotated with the OrientationAngle. The remaining local axis is determined by the right hand rule.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: A rigid link object defining rigid constraints between two or more nodes.

properties.name: PrimaryNode
properties.description: A single node to which SecondaryNodes are constrained.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Elements.Node:  0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.

properties.name: SecondaryNodes
properties.description: List of nodes which are constrained to the PrimaryNode.

properties.name: Constraint
properties.description: Defines how SecondaryNodes are constrained to the PrimaryNode. The LinkConstraint describes translation and rotation of SecondaryNodes with respect to the PrimaryNode's coordinate system.  This is a BH.oM.Structure.Constraints.LinkConstraint:  Defines the rigid connectivity between a primary and set of secondary nodes.

properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Defines the status of the Test Information. Designed to be very clear, concrete statuses, with minimal ambiguity.
Enum values:
-Error: The status is such that immediate action should be taken, and workflows should not continue further until this is addressed.
-Pass: Everything is good, as close to perfect as we can get, with no further action needing to be taken.
-Warning: Something hasn't quite gone to plan, but is not sufficient enough to stop everything. It is advised to investigate further before continuing, but you can continue before addressing this.
Defines input data and expected output data for one run of a particular unit test.

properties.name: Inputs
properties.description: Inputs to the method. Inputs are matched based on index in the list, i.e. index 0 in this list will be used as the first parameter of the method tested.

properties.name: Outputs
properties.description: The expected outputs from the method for the provided inputs. The length of this collection will only be greater than one if the method being tested returns an Output<T1,..,Tn>, for which the indices will match the ones of the Output<>. This means methods returning a collection will be seen as returning one object, where the object is the collection.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Defines a data-driven unit test for a specific method. Class defines inputs, method to be run and expected output.

properties.name: Method
properties.description: The method to be tested. For BHoM methods this can be extracted from the BHoMMethodList method in the Reflection_Engine.

properties.name: Data
properties.description: List of input/output pairs to test the method for. Each TestData item corresponds to one run of the method.

properties.name: Fragments
properties.description: This is a BH.oM.Base.FragmentSet

descriptionParts: Class to store an event raised during the execution on a TestResult.

properties.name: Message
properties.description: Message raised during the execution.

properties.name: Status
properties.description: Severity of the message.

properties.name: UTCTime
properties.description: Provides the UTC time of when the event was raised.

properties.name: StackTrace
properties.description: Original location where the event was generated.

descriptionParts: Enum values:
-Undefined
-DataOnlyAvailableInReference
-Deterioration
-Difference
-Equal
-Improvement
-InputDataChanged
-IntroducedDifference
-IntroducedException
-NoAvailableReferenceSet
-RemovedDifference
-RemovedException
Type of difference or error of the result.
Enum values:
-Equal: Pulled object is identical to pushed obejct
-Exception: Something in the process went wrong, making it impossible to compare the object before and after. For example an exception
-Difference: Difference between a pushed and pulled property.

properties.name: Description
properties.description: Describes the focus of the test that this Test Result answers. This is typically for CI processes but should be human readable for ease of use.

properties.name: Status
properties.description: States whether the test was a success or not. Defaults to Error to ensure any defaults are investigated appropriately.

properties.name: Information
properties.description: Information generated during the test.

properties.name: Message
properties.description: A human readable message explaining why this Test Result has turned out the way it has, with potential solutions or links to associated wiki pages.

properties.name: UTCTime
properties.description: Provides the UTC time of when the Test Result was executed.

properties.name: ID
properties.description: Machine readable identifier for the Test Result.

properties.name: ObjectId
properties.description: The hash of the item being evaluated

properties.name: ResultCase
properties.description: The set the result belongs to.

properties.name: ObjectType
properties.description: The type of the object being evaluated.

properties.name: Results
properties.description: Any differences between the input object and the returned object.

properties.name: TimeStep
properties.description: Time of the results creation as OADate

properties.name: ObjectId
properties.description: The name of the item being evaluated

properties.name: ResultCase
properties.description: The set the result belongs to.

properties.name: PropertyId
properties.description: The name of the evaluated property

properties.name: ObjectType
properties.description: The type of the object being evaluated.

properties.name: ObjectId
properties.description: The hashes of the item being evaluated, comma separated

properties.name: ResultCase
properties.description: The sets the result belongs to, comma separated.

properties.name: ObjectType
properties.description: The type of the object being evaluated.

properties.name: TimeStep
properties.description: Not in use

properties.name: Occurrences
properties.description: Number of times a particular difference has been registred.

properties.name: PropertyId
properties.description: The name of the evaluated property. Only applicable for ResultType 'Difference'.

properties.name: AverageDifference
properties.description: Average difference between the input and returned item. Only applicable for Results of type 'Difference' for numerical values.

properties.name: MaximumDifference
properties.description: Maximum difference between the input and returned item. Only applicable for Results of type 'Difference' for numerical values.

properties.name: MaximumDifferenceInputItem
properties.description: Value of the input item for the maximum difference. Only applicable for Results of type 'Difference' for numerical values.

properties.name: MaximumDifferenceReturnedItem
properties.description: Value of the returned item for the maximum difference. Only applicable for Results of type 'Difference' for numerical values.

properties.name: ObjectId
properties.description: The hash of the item being evaluated

properties.name: ResultCase
properties.description: The set the result belongs to.

properties.name: ObjectType
properties.description: The type of the object being evaluated.

properties.name: PropertyId
properties.description: The name of the evaluated property. Empty if result type is Equal or Exception.

properties.name: InputItem
properties.description: The value of the property on input as a string. Empty if result type is Equal or Exception.

properties.name: ReturnedItem
properties.description: The returned value of the property as a string. Empty if result type is Equal or Exception.

properties.name: TimeStep
properties.description: Time of the results creation as OADate

descriptionParts: Define configuration settings for pushing and pulling XML files using the XML Adapter

properties.name: Schema
properties.description: Define the schema which the XML Adapter should be operating with

properties.name: Settings
properties.description: Set optional settings to use when pushing or pulling XML based on the chosen schema

properties.name: WrapNonBHoMObjects
properties.description: If true, the Push action wraps any non-BHoM type into a BH.oM.Adapter.ObjectWrapper, allowing them to make use of the full Adapter workflow.

properties.name: AllowHashForComparing
properties.description: If true and if no specific EqualityComparer is found for the type, Diffing hashes are computed and used to compare the objects.

properties.name: DiffingConfig
properties.description: Configurations for the Diffing hashing. Requires `AllowHashForComparing` to be set to true.  This is a BH.oM.Diffing.DiffingConfig:  General configurations for the Diffing process, including settings for the Hash computation.

properties.name: ReplaceCurtainWalls
properties.description: Set to true if you want to replace curtain walls to have openings the same size as the wall. This is useful for IES exports. Default false

properties.name: ReplaceSolidOpeningsIntoDoors
properties.description: Set to true if you want to replace an opening which is marked as solid into a door. Useful for IES exports. Default false

properties.name: IncludeConstructions
properties.description: Set to true if you want to include construction and material data in the export. Default false

properties.name: FixIncorrectAirTypes
properties.description: Set to true if you want air types with one adjacent space (i.e. external air walls) to have their type fixed based on their tilt. Default false

properties.name: NewFile
properties.description: Set to false if you want to append to a file when pushing XML. If set to true then a file will be created. If a file exists, it will be overwritten. Default true

properties.name: ResultsUnitType
properties.description: Set the unit type for the results to be either SI or Imperial. Default SI

properties.name: ExportDetail
properties.description: Set the detail of your export to be either full (whole building), shell (exterior walls only), or spaces (each individual space as its own XML file). Default full

properties.name: DistanceTolerance
properties.description: Set the tolerance for distance between points to define a 'short' segment which should be removed from export, default is set to BH.oM.Geometry.Tolerance.Distance

properties.name: PlanarTolerance
properties.description: Set tolerance for planar surfaces, default is set to BH.oM.Geometry.Tolerance.Distance

properties.name: OffsetDistance
properties.description: Set a distance to offset openings that have a area >= the area of the host panel. Value should be negative. Defaults to -0.001

properties.name: AngleTolerance
properties.description: Set the tolerance for angle calculations when exporting to XML. Default is set to BH.oM.Geometry.Tolerance.Angle

properties.name: RoundingSettings
properties.description: Set the rounding options for numerical outputs to be used within gbXML creation. Default is per the Rounding Settings defaults  This is a BH.oM.XML.GBXML.RoundingSettings

properties.name: UnitSetUp
properties.description: Set the units to be used for the export of a gbXML file. Default units will be in SI using the defaults of the GBXMLSetUp object if none are provided  This is a BH.oM.Adapters.XML.GBXMLUnitSetUp

Defines the XML Schema that is being used within the context of the XML Toolkit
Enum values:
-Undefined
-CSProject: CSProject files are used to work out compiling information for code projects. Typically seen in Visual Studio solution files
-EnergyPlusLoads: EnergyPlusLoads is the XML schema for load results calculated using the EnergyPlus software
-GBXML: gbXML Schema is the Green Building XML Schema, used by environment modelling software for the transfer of building geometry and data to tools such as IES, TAS, and more
-KML: KML is a file format used to display geographic data in an Earth browser such as Google Earth
Enum values:
-Undefined
-SI
-Imperial

In case of combining this request with FilterByLink, the Scope Box will be sought for in both link document as well as the host document.

properties.name: PersistentId
properties.description: Persistent identifier of the object in the external software, imported through an Adapter.'Persistent' means that the identifier must be: globally unique and referring to exactly one object in the external software; generated once upon object creation in the external software; never changing throughout the life of the object in the external software.If all these requirements are satisfied, the PersistentId imported from the external software can be used for Diffing purposes.

A data fragment used to store Density values if provided from the EPD source.
Density is a required property for all Evaluations of EPDs with Mass-QuantityType.Density can be changed by the user by adding this fragment to an EPD.
The user accepts responsibility for any changes beyond the given dataset information as not all EPDs will contain Density values.
A data fragment used to store irregular scaling values for EPDs.
Note this fragment is typically reserved for special circumstances requiring user override of documented EPD information.
Use AddFragment() to combine this information with any EPD for continuous integration.

Sets modifiers to a SectionProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

Sets modifiers to a SurfaceProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

A data tree which is traversed through DomainBoxes. Each node's DomainBox is assumed to be enclosed by its parent's DomainBox and to enclose its own data. All the tree's data is stored in its leaves.
A multidimensional domain, defined by the minimum and maximum values in each dimension, enclosing a hypercube.
A numerical domain defined by a minimum and maximum value.
Defines the list of types that are a valid target for this.
Provides the names that were previously used for a given input. If multiple names, use a ',' to separate them.
Warning to be generated when an instance of the containing class is generated with this property set to its default value.
Marks a property as mandatory input when creating an instance of its containing class.
Prevents an auto-constructor component to be available in the UI for the targeted class. This means that `Engine.Create` methods will be the only option to generate instances of that class in the UI.
Settings to determine the uniqueness of an Object.
Stores the hash of the parent BHoMObject.
A plane curve. A circular Arc, a curve, with a constant distance from a point, its centre, defined it the local angular domain between start and end angle.
A plane curve. Standard circle defining a curve of constant distance from a point, its Centre.
A plane curve. A standard ellipse defining a curve of constant combined distance around two foci.
The larger of the two radii defines the major axis of the Ellipse, and the line along which the two foci lie.
A straight segment in space defining the shortest distance between two points in three-dimensional Euclidean geometry.
The Vector from Start to End defines the Line direction, which can be important for some applications.
A non-uniform rational basis spline (or B-spline). Enables definition of smooth and continuous curves as piece-wise polynomial basis functions evaluated from discrete geometrical ControlPoints.
A NurbsCurve, through its use of ControlPoint Weightings, has the ability to precisely represent the conic sections, such as the circle and parabolas etc.

A composite curve constructed by combining a collection of curves of any type. Whole PolyCurve integrity, continuity and closure is not guaranteed at creation. Discontinuous and/or multi-region definitions are possible, although not recommended as may cause unexpected results in method operating on PolyCurves.
A curve consisting of a continuous chain of straight line segments. The Polyline is considered closed if the first and last ControlPoints are coincident
Describes a discrete finite slice of an area. Used for numerical approximation of an integration.
A triangular or quadrilateral shape forming the basis of a polygon Mesh. Defined by corner vertices referencing indices of a Point list. See BH.oM.Geometry.Mesh object for usage.
A value of -1 for the fourth vertex D indicates the Face is triangular.
Details the index of the cells which is behind and infront of each Face.
A polygon mesh, defined by a list of triangular or quadrilateral Faces, Cells and their Vertices.
A polygon mesh, defined by a list of triangular or quadrilateral Faces and their Vertices.
An axis aligned cuboid, which describes the smallest volume Box, oriented with the global coordinate system, that fully encompases a set of geometry.
Defined by its two extreme corner Points, these six coordinate values of Min and Max X, Y and Z are combined to specify all eight Box corners.

A collection of multiple sets of Geometry of any or mixed type. Integrity, continuity and closure is not guaranteed. Discontinuous and/or mixed type definitions are possible, with no restrictions placed on how geometry can be combined.
A four-dimensional vector, useful in calculation of affine transformations in three-dimensional space. See also BH.oM.Geometry.TransformMatrix.
A pair of curves representing the boundary of a trimmed surface in both global X, Y, Z coordinates (Curve3d) as well as local surface U, V parameter space (Curve2d).
A Surface Trim is immutable to ensure compatiblity of both curves.
A 4x4 matrix describing linear tranformations in three-dimensional space, such as translations, rotations, reflections, scaling and shearing.
Solid representation defined by a collection of connected surfaces forming a closed volume
A solid circular right angled cone
A polyhedron. Standard cuboid consisting of six right-angled quadrilateral faces.
A solid circular right angled cylinder.
Standard sphere defining the closed bounding surface of constant distance from a point, its Centre
A standard solid circular ring torus, formed as a surface of revolution of a circle about an axis.
A constant cross section surface, defined by a single profile curve and a linear axis.
A free-form surface defined by a series of cross sectional Curves. The surface provides a continuous interpolation passing through each Curve in order.

A free-form surface constructed as a UV grid of weighted NURBS ControlPoints. A continuous form is generated by approximating a two-directional network of piece-wise polynomial splines across the U and V directions, creating a smooth surface patch.
Supports Inner and Outer Trim Curves which enable greater flexibility in final shape through allowing free-form boundaries to be cut across the underlying UV surface domain.
A NurbsSurface is immutable as its defining properties are not mutually perpendicular to facilitate robust conversion between platforms.
See also BH.oM.Geometry.NurbsCurve for more info on non-uniform rational basis spline (or B-spline) weightings and other parameters.
A constant circular cross section surface, following a defined curve path.
A surface defined by boundary edge curves lying in a common plane. Planarity toleraces default to the BH.oM.Geometry.Tolerace.Distance.

A composite surface constructed by combining a collection of surfaces of any type. Whole PolySurface integrity, continuity and closure is not guaranteed at creation. Discontinuous and/or multi-region definitions are possible, although validity of some engine methods may vary depending on the PolySurface form.
An ordered set of mutually orthogonal unit vectors defining three-dimensional orientation in space
Defines a flat infinite two-dimensional surface
Defines a dimensionless location in three-dimensional space.
Defines a direction and magnitude in three-dimensional Euclidean space.
A three-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system, as defined by a set of mutually orthogonal unit vectors and a common origin point
An individual Grid 'line' - can be curved or free-form as well as simple linear line segments.
Useful for coordination and setting out of spatial objects for transdisciplinary workflows.
Defines a horizontal plane, or infinite flat two-dimensional surface, based on a height measured along the global Z axis and origin.
An acoustics room is defined by the criteria related to the sound within the space, as well as its geometry

Fragment containing gas material properties
Fragment containing solid material properties related to material
The Acoustics object defines the noise criteria for an environments space, whether it's the prescribed ductwork velocity, the noise rating for the space or the dB level.
Equipment gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by specified equipment within the space (dishwasher, oven, etc)
Exhaust is indicative of the amount of air that should be extracted from a space based on the space type (eg laboratory, woodshop) or fixtures contained within the space (eg toilets, showers)
Infiltration gains are defined as the amount of heat or heat loss contributed by cracks in the exterior envelope of the building which allow unconditioned outside air to be introduced to the space
Lighting gains are defined as the amount of heat contributed by light fixtures

The fire protection attributes of a space are indicative of the hazard level of the space (which influences the sprinkler count), the sprinkler system type required, and the presence of combustible materials or sloped ceilings.
The plumbing attributes of a space are indicative of the amount of cold water, hot water and waste required by a space, as well as requirements for vent, floor drains, hose bibs or natural gas
People gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by people based on their assumed activity level within the space (dancing, sitting, etc)
Plug gains are defined as the amount of sensible heat contributed by electrical receptacle/outlet loads
Pollutant gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by pollutution sources.
Ventilation defines the amount of outside air that should be introduced to a space, which is typically based on the number of occupants breathing the air and the area of the space.
A profile object represents a gain, thermostat or humdistat as conditions vary over a 24-hour period
A results object containing diffuse horizontal radiation data.
A results object containing direct normal radiation data.
A results object containing humidity ratio data.

A results object containing relative humidity data.
A collection of results associated with a point-in-time.

A space object is an analytical depiction of a room defined by its environmental conditions (internal gains)
Defines the design options for Openings.

Defines a uniquely identifiable point on the Earth in standard global Latitude, Longitude and Elevation, coordinate system. Particularly useful for specifying local climate conditions for environmental analysis.
Represents a specific moment in time related to a specific location of Earth geometry. Used for obtaining solar positions for specific moments in time at specific points on Earth
An environment object used to describe time for climate analysis
An environment object used to define the position of the sun (in azimuth and elevation)

An AnalysisGrid is used to define an area in 3D space that should be analysed for a given set of results, e.g. daylighting levels, wind levels, heat indexes, etc. - an AnalysisGrid can be used to represent a measurable bit of the environment, including a void in a space, or it can be used to represent a mesh on a panel for analysis
0D finite element for environmental analysis. Node class contains positional information and is used to build AnalysisGrids and provide links between model geometry and analytical results.
Resulting section forces in local coordinates along the bar.

Property for 2D analytical fabric panel elements.

Create a SettingsIES object for use with the IES Adapter
A comment on an Issue typically identifying either the nature of the issue, the actions being taken to resolve the issue, or the approval / rejection of actions taken.
An issue belonging to an audit
Installation progress in a specific area associated with an audit, including image filepaths as applicable
An audit that covers all information associated with a single inspection. This includes issues, areas inspected, project information, construction progress, and distribution information.
An Environmental Metric is used to store data regarding the environmental impacts of a given Environmental Product Declaration.
An EPD can host multiple EnvironmentalMetrics to describe the overall impact which will be used in any LCA calculation.
Fire Protection Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope

The Enclosures Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Foundations Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Life Cycle Assessment Scope object intends to provide a means of reporting all of the project criteria (name, area, type, location). This object may be used for studies at any stage of development and can serve as a true means of 'apples to apples' comparison when catalogued. The information provided within this object is utilised for database construction and organisation only, therefore all values will not effect the overall life cycle assessment results.
Mechanical Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope
Electrical Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope
Plumbing Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope

The MEP Scope object provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within this Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment

The Life Cycle Assessment Scope object intends to provide a means of reporting all of the project criteria (name, area, type, location) as well as the objects that the study encompassed (structural slabs, foundation walls, etc) along with their properties for the Enviornmental Product Declarations they used (when using SetProperty), their densities and volumes. This object may be used for studies at any stage of development and can serve as a true means of 'apples to apples' comparison when catalogued.

The Structures Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Tenant Improvement Scope object provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within this Life Cycle Assessments. Note that this category is not commonly assessed, but will provide for higher quality results. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.
Gives the total quantity of the specified Environmental Product Declaration Field of an object based on its EnvironmentalProductDeclaration.
Gives the total GlobalWarmingPotential of an object based on its EnvironmentalProductDeclaration.
Base class for a LifeCycleAssessment of a single object. This contains the total quantity of global warming potential, acidification potential, etc. for a whole project.
Result class for a LifeCycleAssessment of a whole project. This is used to get the total quantity in terms of embodied carbon, acidification, etc. for a whole project.
A collection of simplified project results commonly used for database collection.

An Environmental Product Declaration or EPD is an independently verified and registered document that communicates transparent and comparable information about the life-cycle environmental impact of products in a credible way.
More information can be found on the Environdec website (environdec.com/all-about-epds0/all-about-epds.)

All EPDs within the BHoM have been provided for general use and are updated as frequently as possible, but by using any supplied EPDs you assume all responsibility for the data used on any applications.
For additional comments, questions, or feature requests, please visit the LifeCycleAssessment_Toolkit at github.com/BHoM/LifeCycleAssessment_Toolkit.
A data fragment used to store Density values if provided from the EPD source.
Density is a required property for all Evaluations of EPDs with Mass-QuantityType.Density can be changed by the user by adding this fragment to an EPD.
The user accepts responsibility for any changes beyond the given dataset information as not all EPDs will contain Density values.
A data fragment used to store irregular scaling values for EPDs.
Note this fragment is typically reserved for special circumstances requiring user override of documented EPD information.
Use AddFragment() to combine this information with any EPD for continuous integration.
A data fragment containing other optional information regarding the production and documentation of any Environmental Product Declaration.
Use AddFragment() to combine this information with any EPD for continuous integration.
Base class for all discrete mesh element results, that is a result for an individual node. Stores all identifier information and how to sort the results in a collection
Full collection of discrete results for an AnalysisGrid for a specific Analysis.
Lux contains results for Lux analysis. Inherits from MeshElementResult which provides properties related to which node this Lux is recorded for
A LuminaireType containing manufacturer, dimensional, and other property data applied to a Luminaire.

An AnalysisGrid is used to define an area in 3D space that should be analysed for a given set of results, e.g. daylighting levels, wind levels, heat indexes, etc. - an AnalysisGrid can be used to represent a measurable bit of the environment, including a void in a space, or it can be used to represent a mesh on a panel for analysis
0D finite element for lighting analysis. Node class contains positional information and is used to build AnalysisGrids and provide links between model geometry and analytical results
A Cable Tray object is a passageway which conveys material (typically cables)
A duct object is a passageway which conveys material (typically air)
Mechanical systems are qualified by their ability to convey air, water, etc to a building/room/area
0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.
A pipe object is a passageway which conveys material (water, waste, glycol)
A collection of IFlow Objects to be utilised throughout a defined system.
An object containing a collection of Wires to work within an MEP systems.
Wire object to work within an MEP systems.
A fitting object used to describe interfaces between or along linear MEP elements.
A device used to control the flow within a duct system (fire smoke damper, volume damper, etc.)
A type of damper used to control the flow of air in a mechanical system.
A device used to control the flow within a piping system (ball valve, check valve, etc.)
A device used to warn building occupants of emergencies (smoke, fire, carbon monoxide) by means of audio or visual appliances (smoke detectors, speaker strobes, heat detectors.)
A device used to convey electricity e.g. duplex sockets/receptacles, disconnect/isolator switches (for electrified mechanical equipment), floors boxes.
A device used to convey public health (plumbing) fluids (water, waste.)

A device used to regulate the volume of air to or from an air handling unit, variable air volume device or similar, to or from the occupied space. These devices may be ducted or connect directly to a plenum, in which case no duct connection will be present.
Flow properties of a plumbing fixture
Fixture Usage data for residential plumbing fixtures.
Fixture Usage data for commercial plumbing fixtures.
A light fixture is an electrical device that provides illumination.
Air Handling Units are devices which house fans, filter, coils, and energy wheels which produce heated and cooled fresh/partially recirculated air to a building
Fan Coil Units are devices that use a coil and a fan to heat or cool a space
Air Handling Units are devices which house fans, filter, coils, and energy wheels which produce heated and cooled fresh/partially recirculated air to a building
Cooling coils allow fluids (air) to lower their temperature as they pass through the coil
Electrical Connectors are the devices (motors, disconnects/isolators) that serve as a source of power for mechanical equipment
Energy wheels are devices that capture sensible and/or latent heat from air which would otherwise be lost to the atmosphere
Filters are devices that remove solid particles from a system
Heating coils allow fluids (air) to raise their temperature as they pass through the coil
Fans are devices that create a current of air (used for ventilation and cooling) by rotating blades

On Push it can be used to generate or update Revit model elements that do not have a correspondent BHoM type, on Pull all Revit model elements that do not have explicit Convert method for given discipline will be converted to ModelInstance.

A camera object is a electronic security device typically used in closed-circuit television (CCTV) systems.
L-shaped profile.
Rectangular hollow profile with constant thickness and optional corner radii.
C-shaped profile with parallel flanges of the same length and thickness.
Solid circular profile
Rectangular hollow profile that allows for different thicknesses of the webs, top flange and bottom flange.
I-shaped profile with parallel flanges that allows for different thicknesses of the web, top flange and bottom flange as well as different top and bottom flange widths.
Freeform profile only defined by its geometry without any dimensional data. To be used as a fallback for profiles not yet explicitly defined.
Rectangular hollow profile that allows for different thicknesses of the webs, top flange and bottom flange as well as defined outstands of the top and bottom flange
T-shaped profile that allows for different outsand widths and thicknesses. Outstands with different thicknesses are aligned by their top edge.
The full width of the top flange can be calculated as LeftOutstandWidth + WebThickness + RightOutstandWidth.
I-shaped profile with parallel flanges with equal thickness.
Solid rectangular profile.
T-shaped profile with constant flange thickness.
Circular hollow profile.
Layout for freeform control over the point distribution
Layout for freeform control over the curve distribution.
Curve layout created by offsetting an element's outer and inner outlines.
Positive offset value will offset to the inside of the element.
Linear distribution of points along a vector from one side of the perimeter of the host object to the other.
Linear distribution of points along multiple linear parallel axes, defined along a vector from one side of the perimeter of the host object to the other.
Starts by fitting in as many points as possible in the first layer, then generates a new one and repeats.
Linear distribution of points along the perimeter of the host object.

This object can be used to group geometry to push to a specific file. Useful if pushing groups of geometry related to specific representations, for example, a group of panels to one file, and a group of bars to another.
Class defining offsets for bar objects from its end Nodes to be applied in analysis packages.
Property for 2D analytical elements, made up of a slab on top of parallel ribs running in one direction, all sharing the same material.
Property for 2D analytical elements, made up of a slab on top of parallel ribs running in two directions, all sharing the same material.
Simplest property for 2D analytical elements with a constant thickness and homogenous material across the whole element.
Property for 2D analytical elements used to distribute load, without any structural stiffness.
Defines the  reinforcement of a Panel in the longitudinal and transverse direction specified by the Basis of the ReinforcementRegion.
If the diameter of the reinforcement is set to 0, it will be assumed that no reinforcement is present in this direction.
A collection of PanelReinforcement objects that represent the rebar intent.
This is stored as layers of reinforcement amongst regions within the Panel.
A collection of reinforcement for a Bar and minimum cover.
A region defining the area of a Panel to be reinforced. The curve must exist within the 2D region outlined by ExternalEdges of the Panel.
Defines any transverse reinforcement along a Bar.
Defines any longitudinal reinforcement along a Bar.
Aluminium section to be used on Bars. Defined by a section profile.
Material agnostic section. To be used for sections of material types not yet explicitly supported.
Timber section to be used on Bars. Defined by a section profile.
Cable section to be used on Bars. Defined by cable diameter, number of cables, and total area.
A steel-concrete composite section to be used on bars. Defined by a steel and a concrete section. Not yet fully implemented/Supported.
Concrete section to be used on Bars. Defined by a section profile. Note that all section constants are assuming an uncracked section and are disregarding reinforcement.
Material agnostic section. Does not own any geometry. Allows explicit setting of all section constants.
Steel section to be used on Bars. Defined by a section profile.

Resulting local deformation of the Bar in local coordinates. This is disregarding rigid body motion and/or rotation of the Bar.

Sets modifiers to a SectionProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

Sets modifiers to a SurfaceProperty. The modifiers are used to scale one or more of the property constants for analysis. Constants are multiplied with the modifiers, hence a modifier value of 1 means no change.

1D finite element for structural analysis. Linear 2-noded element defined by a start and end node.For structural conventions and orientation of the bar please see https://github.com/BHoM/documentation/wiki/BHoM-Structural-Conventions.
Edge class to describe the edges of panels (or other objects) by a curve and properties.
2D finite element mesh for structural analysis. Defined by a list of nodes and faces.
Face of an FEMesh. The face is defined by the indices of its nodes in the node list. Geometrical information about position in space is stored on the host FEMesh.
0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.
Opening of a structural Panel object. Can be used to represent, for example, shafts, windows, and doors.
2D element for structural analysis.
The Surface is a freeform surface object defined by a geometrical surface. For planar elements, the Panel is recommended, as it is generally better supported in analysis packages.
2D element for structural analysis.
The Panel is a planar surface object defined by a list of planar 'Edges' (curves with properties) for both external and internal edges (openings).
A rigid link object defining rigid constraints between two or more nodes.

Class to store an event raised during the execution on a TestResult.

This can be of the following types: Domain, TargetsAttribute, AbbreviationAttribute, DeprecatedAttribute, PreviousInputNamesAttribute, PreviousVersionAttribute, DefaultValueWarningAttribute, ToBeRemovedAttribute, RequiredAttribute, ReplacedAttribute, NoAutoConstructorAttribute, InputAttribute, InputFromProperty, MultiOutputAttribute, NotImplementedAttribute, and more...
A numerical domain defined by a minimum and maximum value.
Defines the list of types that are a valid target for this.
Provides the names that were previously used for a given input. If multiple names, use a ',' to separate them.
Warning to be generated when an instance of the containing class is generated with this property set to its default value.
Marks a property as mandatory input when creating an instance of its containing class.
Prevents an auto-constructor component to be available in the UI for the targeted class. This means that `Engine.Create` methods will be the only option to generate instances of that class in the UI.
A polygon mesh, defined by a list of triangular or quadrilateral Faces, Cells and their Vertices.
A pair of curves representing the boundary of a trimmed surface in both global X, Y, Z coordinates (Curve3d) as well as local surface U, V parameter space (Curve2d).
A Surface Trim is immutable to ensure compatiblity of both curves.
Solid representation defined by a collection of connected surfaces forming a closed volume

A free-form surface constructed as a UV grid of weighted NURBS ControlPoints. A continuous form is generated by approximating a two-directional network of piece-wise polynomial splines across the U and V directions, creating a smooth surface patch.
Supports Inner and Outer Trim Curves which enable greater flexibility in final shape through allowing free-form boundaries to be cut across the underlying UV surface domain.
A NurbsSurface is immutable as its defining properties are not mutually perpendicular to facilitate robust conversion between platforms.

descriptionParts: The fileSettings, file name and directory, to use with an adapter for push and pull
An individual Grid 'line' - can be curved or free-form as well as simple linear line segments.
Useful for coordination and setting out of spatial objects for transdisciplinary workflows.
Defines a horizontal plane, or infinite flat two-dimensional surface, based on a height measured along the global Z axis and origin.
An acoustics room is defined by the criteria related to the sound within the space, as well as its geometry
A set of IBHoMObject entities and the relations between them.
Geometry projection for Graphs.
Base class for all Relation classes.
Graphical projection for Graphs.
Spatial Projection for Graphs.
Used for orientation and setting out of tier profiles
Object representing a builders work opening as an entity independent of its host.
Represents a code variable in the context of a BHoM abstract syntax tree.
Points to a specific Stream. Can be used to generate a new Stream and StreamId.
Fragment containing gas material properties
Fragment containing solid material properties related to material
The Acoustics object defines the noise criteria for an environments space, whether it's the prescribed ductwork velocity, the noise rating for the space or the dB level.
Equipment gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by specified equipment within the space (dishwasher, oven, etc)
Exhaust is indicative of the amount of air that should be extracted from a space based on the space type (eg laboratory, woodshop) or fixtures contained within the space (eg toilets, showers)
Infiltration gains are defined as the amount of heat or heat loss contributed by cracks in the exterior envelope of the building which allow unconditioned outside air to be introduced to the space
Lighting gains are defined as the amount of heat contributed by light fixtures

The fire protection attributes of a space are indicative of the hazard level of the space (which influences the sprinkler count), the sprinkler system type required, and the presence of combustible materials or sloped ceilings.
The plumbing attributes of a space are indicative of the amount of cold water, hot water and waste required by a space, as well as requirements for vent, floor drains, hose bibs or natural gas
People gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by people based on their assumed activity level within the space (dancing, sitting, etc)
Plug gains are defined as the amount of sensible heat contributed by electrical receptacle/outlet loads
Pollutant gains are defined as the amount of both latent and sensible heat contributed by pollutution sources.
Ventilation defines the amount of outside air that should be introduced to a space, which is typically based on the number of occupants breathing the air and the area of the space.
A profile object represents a gain, thermostat or humdistat as conditions vary over a 24-hour period
A results object containing diffuse horizontal radiation data.
A results object containing direct normal radiation data.
A results object containing humidity ratio data.
A results object containing power data.
A results object containing insolation data.
A results object containing global horizontal radiation data.
A results object containing dry bulb temperature data.
A results object containing illuminance data.
A results object containing Universal Thermal Climate Index data.
A results object containing sky temperature data.
A results object containing dew point temperature data.
A results object containing enthalpy data.
A results object containing wind-direction data.
A results object containing atmospheric pressure data.
A collection of DateTimes associated with a time-series result.
A results object containing wind speed data
A results object containing surface temperature data.
A results object containing wet bulb temperature data.
A results object containing mean radiant temperature data.
A results object containing relative humidity data.
A collection of results associated with a point-in-time.
A Environment Profile Result object that can be added to a Simulation Result
An Environment Simulation Result object
This building object is used for setting the location and building type, which is required for some environmental workflows
A zone of the external faces of an Environment Mesh.
A self-contained unit of accommodation, that could contain smaller spaces
An environment object used to define a volumetric mesh.
An environment object used to define an edge of an external boundary (e.g. the edge of an environmental panel or opening)
A cutout or hole in a building surface/panel (e.g. Window, Door, Rooflight)
An environmental object used to define planar surfaces of a space (e.g. Wall, Floor, Roof)
A space object is an analytical depiction of a room defined by its environmental conditions (internal gains)
Defines the design options for Openings.

Defines a uniquely identifiable point on the Earth in standard global Latitude, Longitude and Elevation, coordinate system. Particularly useful for specifying local climate conditions for environmental analysis.
Represents a specific moment in time related to a specific location of Earth geometry. Used for obtaining solar positions for specific moments in time at specific points on Earth
An environment object used to describe time for climate analysis
An environment object used to define the position of the sun (in azimuth and elevation)

An AnalysisGrid is used to define an area in 3D space that should be analysed for a given set of results, e.g. daylighting levels, wind levels, heat indexes, etc. - an AnalysisGrid can be used to represent a measurable bit of the environment, including a void in a space, or it can be used to represent a mesh on a panel for analysis
0D finite element for environmental analysis. Node class contains positional information and is used to build AnalysisGrids and provide links between model geometry and analytical results.
Frame edge (eg mullion, window jamb, curtain wall sill, etc) property with list of Profile Section properties that make up the mullion construction.
An overall thermal transmittance result representing the effective U-Value of an object or collection of objects.
A frame edge (eg mullion, window jamb, curtain wall sill, etc)
A facade object used to define a curtain wall made up of multiple openings.
A cutout or hole in a building surface/panel (e.g. Window, Rooflight)
A facade object used to define planar surfaces such as walls
A Directory. It can include the content of the Directory.
A FileSystem-hosted Directory. It can include the content of the Directory.
A File. It can include the content of the File.
A FileSystem-hosted File. It can include the content of the File.
Defines options for the Representation of BHoM Objects.
Defines options for the Meshing of BHoM Objects.
Scale for mapping from a discrete domain and range.
Configuration properties for view objects.
Basic arrow head marker.
Basic link representation for relationships between entities.
Rectangular box configuration for representation of entity boundaries.
Property for 2D analytical fabric panel elements.
Property for spacer elements.
Soap film property for 1D element.
Soap film property for 2D element.
A spacer defining an edge of a fabric panel in GSA.
Create a SettingsIES object for use with the IES Adapter
A comment on an Issue typically identifying either the nature of the issue, the actions being taken to resolve the issue, or the approval / rejection of actions taken.
An issue belonging to an audit
Installation progress in a specific area associated with an audit, including image filepaths as applicable
An audit that covers all information associated with a single inspection. This includes issues, areas inspected, project information, construction progress, and distribution information.
An Environmental Metric is used to store data regarding the environmental impacts of a given Environmental Product Declaration.
An EPD can host multiple EnvironmentalMetrics to describe the overall impact which will be used in any LCA calculation.
Fire Protection Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope

The Enclosures Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Foundations Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Life Cycle Assessment Scope object intends to provide a means of reporting all of the project criteria (name, area, type, location). This object may be used for studies at any stage of development and can serve as a true means of 'apples to apples' comparison when catalogued. The information provided within this object is utilised for database construction and organisation only, therefore all values will not effect the overall life cycle assessment results.
Mechanical Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope
Electrical Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope
Plumbing Scope provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within the MEPScope

The MEP Scope object provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within this Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment

The Life Cycle Assessment Scope object intends to provide a means of reporting all of the project criteria (name, area, type, location) as well as the objects that the study encompassed (structural slabs, foundation walls, etc) along with their properties for the Enviornmental Product Declarations they used (when using SetProperty), their densities and volumes. This object may be used for studies at any stage of development and can serve as a true means of 'apples to apples' comparison when catalogued.

The Structures Scope object provides a template for expected objects commonly assessed within Life Cycle Assessments. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

The Tenant Improvement Scope object provides a template for expected objects to be assessed within this Life Cycle Assessments. Note that this category is not commonly assessed, but will provide for higher quality results. Please provide as many objects with their corresponding Environmental Product Declaration data for the most accurate Life Cycle Assessment.

An Environmental Product Declaration or EPD is an independently verified and registered document that communicates transparent and comparable information about the life-cycle environmental impact of products in a credible way.
More information can be found on the Environdec website (environdec.com/all-about-epds0/all-about-epds.)

All EPDs within the BHoM have been provided for general use and are updated as frequently as possible, but by using any supplied EPDs you assume all responsibility for the data used on any applications.
For additional comments, questions, or feature requests, please visit the LifeCycleAssessment_Toolkit at github.com/BHoM/LifeCycleAssessment_Toolkit.
A LuminaireType containing manufacturer, dimensional, and other property data applied to a Luminaire.

An AnalysisGrid is used to define an area in 3D space that should be analysed for a given set of results, e.g. daylighting levels, wind levels, heat indexes, etc. - an AnalysisGrid can be used to represent a measurable bit of the environment, including a void in a space, or it can be used to represent a mesh on a panel for analysis
0D finite element for lighting analysis. Node class contains positional information and is used to build AnalysisGrids and provide links between model geometry and analytical results
A Cable Tray object is a passageway which conveys material (typically cables)
A duct object is a passageway which conveys material (typically air)
Mechanical systems are qualified by their ability to convey air, water, etc to a building/room/area
0D finite element for structural analysis. Node class contains positional information as well as orientation and support.
A pipe object is a passageway which conveys material (water, waste, glycol)
A collection of IFlow Objects to be utilised throughout a defined system.
An object containing a collection of Wires to work within an MEP systems.
Wire object to work within an MEP systems.
A fitting object used to describe interfaces between or along linear MEP elements.
A device used to control the flow within a duct system (fire smoke damper, volume damper, etc.)
A type of damper used to control the flow of air in a mechanical system.
A device used to control the flow within a piping system (ball valve, check valve, etc.)
A device used to warn building occupants of emergencies (smoke, fire, carbon monoxide) by means of audio or visual appliances (smoke detectors, speaker strobes, heat detectors.)
A device used to convey electricity e.g. duplex sockets/receptacles, disconnect/isolator switches (for electrified mechanical equipment), floors boxes.
A device used to convey public health (plumbing) fluids (water, waste.)

A device used to regulate the volume of air to or from an air handling unit, variable air volume device or similar, to or from the occupied space. These devices may be ducted or connect directly to a plenum, in which case no duct connection will be present.
Flow properties of a plumbing fixture
Fixture Usage data for residential plumbing fixtures.
Fixture Usage data for commercial plumbing fixtures.
A light fixture is an electrical device that provides illumination.
Air Handling Units are devices which house fans, filter, coils, and energy wheels which produce heated and cooled fresh/partially recirculated air to a building
Fan Coil Units are devices that use a coil and a fan to heat or cool a space
Air Handling Units are devices which house fans, filter, coils, and energy wheels which produce heated and cooled fresh/partially recirculated air to a building
Cooling coils allow fluids (air) to lower their temperature as they pass through the coil
Electrical Connectors are the devices (motors, disconnects/isolators) that serve as a source of power for mechanical equipment
Energy wheels are devices that capture sensible and/or latent heat from air which would otherwise be lost to the atmosphere
Filters are devices that remove solid particles from a system
Heating coils allow fluids (air) to raise their temperature as they pass through the coil
Fans are devices that create a current of air (used for ventilation and cooling) by rotating blades
A BoundingBox defines a region for searches using the cardinal limits.
A CentreRadius defines a region for searches within a radius around Node.
A LineStringRadius defines a region for searches within a radius around polygon.
A node is one of the core elements in the OpenStreetMap data model. It consists of a single point in space defined by its latitude, longitude and node id.
Container for OpenStreetMap elements returned from a query.
A Polygon defines a region for searches based on a collection of nodes.
A QueryBuilder constructs the OpenStreetMap query from a set of regions to search within and elements to search for.
The OpenStreetMap Overpass API query statement in Overpass QL format.
A relation is a group of elements (Members) used to model logical (and usually local) or geographic relationships between objects.
A TaggedArea defines a region for searches with a set of geographic attributes.
A Way is an ordered list of nodes which normally also has at least one tag or is included within a Relation.
Defining reinforcement running along the element.
Defining shear reinforcement for framing elements.
Defines the make up of an object through a list of Materials as relative proportions of the total solid volume.
There must be the same number of items in both lists, assigning a single Ratio for each Material.
A layer object with given material and thickness
Represents a group of syntax nodes covered by a common description. This is equivalent to a block of code inside a method.
Represents a cluster of syntax nodes. This is equivalent to a method declaration.
A syntax node representing a call to a constructor.
A syntax node representing the creation of a BHoM Custom object.
A syntax node corresponding to a call to the BHoM Explode method/component.
A syntax node corresponding to a call to the BHoM GetProperty method/component.
A syntax node representing the initialisation of an object.
In C#, this would be equivalent to something like 'new Point {X = x, Y = y }'
A syntax node corresponding to a call to the CreateData BHoM component.
A syntax node corresponding to a code loop.
A syntax node representing a call to a method.
A syntax node that is in itself a single data parameter.
A syntax node corresponding to a call to the BHoM SetProperty method/component.
A syntax node representing the creation of an object Type.
Content of a Cluster syntax node.
A group of syntax nodes referenced by their Guid.
Output of a syntax node.
Input of a syntax node.

Library of Revit families that can be loaded to the model.
Wrapper for Revit family file (.rfa) that stores basic information about it such as family category, familiy type names etc.
Revit family load settings for Revit Adapter. Prototype, currently with limited functionality.
Socket connection settings for Revit Adapter.
